title: 110_hr2865
content: The Act may be cited as the "Rabbi Arthur Schneier Congressional Gold Medal Act". Rabbi Arthur Schneier has been recognized for his efforts in promoting religious freedom and human rights worldwide for nearly 50 years. He has received awards from multiple U.S. administrations and the Department of State for his work in fostering mutual understanding, tolerance, and peace. In China in 2004, Rabbi Schneier led an interfaith delegation advocating for religious freedom and fostering exchanges between religious communities. He has also been actively involved in promoting peace and easing tensions in countries like Armenia and Yugoslavia. Rabbi Schneier led interfaith efforts in former Yugoslavia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, and at the United Nations to promote peace and protect holy sites. In 1980, Rabbi Schneier initiated the Annual Seminar on Religious Life to educate Foreign Service officers about the religious traditions of their assigned countries. He was honored by the Foreign Service Institute in 2001 for his 20 years of cooperation in promoting religious freedom. Rabbi Schneier has also been active in humanitarian missions, including mobilizing the American religious community to support victims of earthquakes in Armenia and Turkey. He has served as a United States Alternate Representative to the United Nations General Assembly and Chairman of the United States Commission for the Preservation of America's Heritage Abroad. Rabbi Arthur Schneier, born in Vienna in 1930, lived under Nazi occupation in Budapest during WWII and later moved to the United States in 1947. He holds an Ordination and Doctor of Divinity Degree from Yeshiva University. In 2004, Yeshiva University established the Rabbi Arthur Schneier Center for International Affairs in his honor. Rabbi Arthur Schneier will be presented with a Congressional Gold Medal for his efforts in promoting religious freedom and human rights worldwide. The medal will be designed and struck by the Secretary of the Treasury. Additionally, duplicate medals will be made. The Secretary has the authority to create duplicate bronze medals of the gold medal, sell them at a price to cover costs, and designate them as national medals. All medals struck under this Act are considered numismatic items. Proceeds from the sale will be used as authorized. SEC. 6. AUTHORITY TO USE FUND AMOUNTS; PROCEEDS OF SALE. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund can be used to pay for the costs of the medal struck under this Act. Proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited back into the Fund.
